content: The conditions for 11# coal seam are mainly mudstone and sandy mudstone, with well-developed fractures, which are prone to collapse during mining. The average dip angle of the coal seam at the working face is 4°, and the thickness of the coal seam ranges from 1.38 to 1.92 m, with an average of 1.6 m. Under these conditions, if a fault structure occurs along with the development of associated fractures, it may lead to roof fragmentation, difficulty in roof management, and potentially trigger roof accidents.

Anchor bolt support technology Use high-strength left-handed reinforcement-free anchor rods with a diameter of 20mm, with a top anchor rod length of 2200mm and side anchor rod length of 1800mm. The spacing of the top anchor rods is 1000mm with a center distance of 1100mm, and the spacing between the side anchors is also 1000mm.

Anchor cable support technology Use a 7-strand steel stranded anchor cable with a diameter of 17.8mm, a breaking load of 360kN, with a spacing of 1800mm, a row distance of 2000mm, two cables per row, arranged vertically 1600mm from the coal wall to the roof.
Reinforced welded mesh support Used in conjunction with anchor rods and anchor cables to form a support system of anchor rod + anchor cable + welded steel mesh.

The conditions include deep coal seams, high and concentrated geostress, high coal seam gas content (relative gas emission of 21.1 m³/t), and high gas pressure (0.9-1.8 MPa). Under these conditions, gas extraction will face challenges such as soft coal seams and low permeability (gas permeability coefficient of 0.5~2 m²/MPa·2d), which may result in difficulties in meeting extraction standards and pose risks of coal and gas outbursts and gas explosions.

the roof strata from the 3306 bottom extraction tunnel to the coal seam is a 12.5m sandstone cover layer, with a coal seam thickness of 1.7m. Under these conditions, the determination of the gas extraction radius will face the challenge of insufficient accuracy in measurements using the cuttings method and the drilling flow method, which may lead to unclear extraction parameters.

Pressure drop method This technology is applicable for determining the gas extraction radius in layer-crossing drilling, by setting up 6 pressure measurement holes (spacing of 2.0m-6.0m) and extraction holes, and observing the pressure changes in each measurement hole over a period of 7 days to determine the effective extraction radius.

Layered-parallel drilling layout method This technology is suitable for the layout of bottom extraction lane through-layer drilling, with a drilling diameter of 94mm, a drilling depth of 13.5m, and a sealing depth of 10m. It uses a two-plug one-injection bag sealing method, with a cement consumption of no less than 75kg per hole for sealing.

the original gas content value of the coal seam at the 3412 working face is 7.92 m³/t, the original gas pressure value is 0.58 MPa, the maximum absolute gas outburst value is 13.13 m³/min, and the maximum relative gas outburst value is 7.25 m³/t. Under these conditions, mining will face the challenge of high risks of gas accidents, which may trigger multiple secondary disaster incidents, posing a great threat to the safety of production in the mine.

The conditions include a coal seam thickness of 1.58 to 3.21 meters, the development of endogenous fissures, branching of the coal seam, and complex structures. Under these conditions, the gas management will face the challenges of complex gas outflow sources and high difficulty in management, which may affect the effectiveness of gas extraction.

Advanced pre-extraction gas technology before tunnel excavation. This technique is carried out before the excavation of the tunnel, using a VLD-1000 directional drill, with a drilling depth of 300m and a drilling spacing of 12m, to conduct advanced pre-extraction of gas from the unmined area within the solid coal body.

Gas extraction technology of the coal seam during the tunnel excavation period. This technology is used during tunnel excavation, with a production drilling hole for coal seam extraction constructed every 6.3 meters. The depth of the material lane drilling is 80 meters, and the depth of the transportation lane drilling is 100 meters, using FKJW-50/0.5 gas extraction drilling bag-type sealing.

Comprehensive gas management technology during recovery. This technology includes a method that combines fracture zone drilling (arranging 5 boreholes within the drilling site, with a vertical depth of 5 to 10 meters) and upper corner pipe drainage (using a Ф300mm pipeline transformed into two 152.4mm armored pipes).

The conditions involve a drilling depth of 5000 meters, complex drilling structures, and multiple borehole diameter levels. Under these conditions, drilling will face challenges such as high mud flow requirements and high return pressure, which may result in low construction efficiency.

The conditions require the satisfaction of multiple construction processes, including large-diameter construction and small-diameter cable core drilling. Under these conditions, the pump is required to have a wide range of flow rate and pressure changes, which presents the challenge of complex flow regulation and may result in an inability to adapt to different construction processes.

Variable frequency control technology Using a 6-pole variable frequency speed regulating motor, it operates in the constant torque range from 0 to 980 r/min, and in the constant power range from 980 to 1500 r/min, allowing for remote control and stepless flow adjustment.

Two-speed mechanical transmission technology Set up a two-stage gearbox, combined with the characteristics of the variable frequency motor, to achieve a wider range of pump flow (0-1850 L/min) and pump pressure (6.5-39 MPa) regulation at a power output of 250 kW.

Five-cylinder pump technology Using a five-cylinder design, compared to a three-cylinder pump, the flow is more uniform and stable, with lower pressure fluctuations and a lower stroke rate (0-143 strokes/min), which helps extend the lifespan of wear parts and the entire machine.

the 8714 working face is the first mining face, with an average burial depth of 331 m, a coal seam thickness of 5.22 to 6.42 m, and an inclination angle of 2° to 8°. The basic roof is coarse sandstone (thickness 11.34 m), the immediate roof is fine sandstone (thickness 2.70 m), and the pseudo-roof is carbonaceous mudstone (thickness 1.59 m). Under these conditions, mining will face cyclical pressure caused by basic roof breaking, leading to deformation such as sinking of the tunnel roof and floor, and bulging at the bottom. The formation of 'structural block 3' in the goaf will exert a continuous and significant static pressure effect on the tunnel, potentially resulting in severe deformation or even damage to the tunnel.

Advanced pre-cracking cutting seam technology This technology involves construction at least 100 meters ahead of the working face, by severing the connection between the basic roof above the tunnel and the rock layers, forming a short arm beam structure at the tunnel's roof to reduce the impact of the fracture or collapse of the side roof in the mined-out area on the tunnel.

Roof reinforcement support technology This technology involves re-installing defective anchor rods and cables, strengthening the ceiling with reinforcement cables, and erecting a reinforcement canopy, conducted after pre-splitting blasting to reinforce the existing support structure.

Technology for gob-side backfill protection This technology involves installing a debris protection net and erecting debris columns to support areas where the debris does not fully contact the protection net, preventing the collapse of coal gangue from the mined-out area, which could affect the cross-section of the tunnel.

Lagging temporary support technology This technology reduces the amount of roof subsidence and minimizes the impact of coal gangue falling on the tunnel during pressure surges by installing temporary support equipment at the transition between the temporary support area and the end support area.

the N1303 working face is approximately 400 meters away from the cessation line, and there is currently no storage space for electrical trains in the N1303 belt roadway. Under these conditions, moving the equipment train will face the challenge of insufficient space, which may affect the recovery progress or lead to production stoppage.

the total length of the electric train is 335m, with the equipment portion being 175m, the cable self-moving device measuring 160m, and the total weight of the train being 41.8t. Under these conditions, the overall mobile equipment self-moving train is generally not allowed to turn during operation. If production is halted for disassembly, it will take one month, which will severely affect normal production in the mine.

Technology for dismantling the traveling frame's turning mechanism This technology is suitable for flat tunnels or sections with minimal slope. By removing the travel frame and travel cylinder, and using a pull rod connection, it enables the equipment train to turn and move.

Track modification technology This technology is applicable at turning points, utilizing 6 curved tracks, 2 transition tracks, and auxiliary fittings, with a track width of 68mm, height of 155mm, and a middle plate thickness of 7mm, allowing for the safe passage of equipment.

the raw coal has an ash content of 45.57%, sulfur content of 3.15%, classified as high ash and high sulfur coal, with a +50mm particle size accounting for 31.83%, ash content at 70.28%, of which the visible gangue content is 23.87%, resulting in an ash content of 84.04%. Under these conditions, if no washing and selection are carried out, the calorific value of the commercial coal will be low (approximately 17.56 MJ/kg), and the high sulfur content will increase the desulfurization costs for the power plants, leading to significant sales pressure.

there are multiple coal seams that can be mined in the mine, with varying thicknesses and significant fluctuations in coal quality. Under these conditions, production will face the challenge of ensuring the stability of raw coal quality, which may result in difficulties in meeting quality requirements.

Heavy media shallow trough separation technology This technology is suitable for sorting coal in the particle size range of 200 to 13 mm, offering high sorting accuracy and product recovery rates. It can control the sorting based on density, making it suitable for both low-density sorting of clean coal and high-density waste removal.

Three-product heavy medium cyclone separation technology This technology is suitable for the separation of coal with particle sizes ranging from 50 to 3 mm, simplifying the medium flow and process links, with a compact arrangement. The use of non-pressurized feeding helps reduce the mudification of gangue and the amount of secondary coal slime.

The conditions indicate a coal-bearing formation with multiple layers, containing a total of 14 coal seams, 6 of which are minable. The spacing between the coal seams is between 22.6 to 44.8 meters, with each coal seam having a thickness of over 1 meter. Under these conditions, extraction will face challenges such as the complex order of coal seam group extraction and the absence of uniform conditions between coal seams, which may result in low extraction efficiency.

The conditions include numerous surface buildings and structures in the wellfield, such as the Dazidang Reservoir dam, the Tai Zhong Yin Railway, and high-voltage lines. Under these conditions, selecting the wellhead location will face challenges such as constraints from ground facilities and large coal compression, which may result in increased project costs and resource losses.

the reservoir is divided into two blocks, east and west, by the DF3 fault, with the western resources accounting for 82% of the total resource amount. Under these conditions, the layout for development will face challenges such as the difficulty of fault crossing and the difficulties of coordinated mining between the eastern and western blocks, which may lead to increased construction difficulty and higher safety risks.

Integrated Layout Mining Technology This technology is applicable to the close-range coal seam group, dividing the six coal layers into two coal groups for joint mining, with the first, third, and fifth layers as the upper group, and the eighth, ninth upper, and ninth layers as the lower group.

Main and auxiliary return three vertical shafts + main石门 development method This technology is suitable for deep mining, with the wellhead elevation at +350m, located in the siltstone above a coal seam, using a horizontal upward mining method.

The conditions are a working face burial depth of 276 to 398 meters, a strike mining length of 1079.7 meters, a dip length of 223.1 meters, and a thickness of coal seam #10 ranging from 1.4 to 2 meters, with an average coal thickness of 1.8 meters. Under these conditions, the coal pillarless mining will face challenges such as poor roof stability and significant deformation of the surrounding rock, which may result in tunnel deformation damage and instability of the surrounding rock.

the basic top of the coal seam is a high-strength K2 limestone. Under these conditions, the top-cut and room-keeping operations will face challenges such as the difficulty of the roof falling and excessive length of the cantilever beam, which may lead to excessive support pressure and deformation of the roadway.

Directional pre-splitting blasting technology This technology is suitable for strong roof cutting, with a cut seam height of 7 m, a seam angle of 15°, a drilling spacing of 500 mm, using emulsified explosives for mining, and 4 energy-concentrating tubes per hole.

Constant resistance anchor cable reinforcement support technology This technology is suitable for maintaining the stability of the top plate during the top-cutting period, laying out three rows of 8.3 m long constant-resistance anchoring cables, with the first row 700 mm from the mined-out side, a spacing of 1200 mm, and a spacing of 1200 mm between the second and third rows, with a spacing of 2400 mm.

Temporary support technology for segmented areas This technology provides support based on the stress characteristics of different positions in the roadway, including the advanced support zone (0-30 m), the temporary support zone behind the framework (0-200 m), and the stable zone of the roadway (beyond 200 m).

The conditions include the presence of a hard roof in the working face, which accounts for approximately 30% of coal seam distribution in our country. The strength of the roof rock layers is relatively high, with sandstone strength ranging from 84-103 MPa at a depth of 0-1.5 meters, and the strength of the huangban rock reaching 75-100 MPa. Under these conditions, mining will face the challenge of the roof being difficult to collapse, which may lead to large areas of the working face being unsupported, creating significant safety hazards for production.

the 8102 working face recovery and the 5100 auxiliary transportation lane excavation intersect, forming a pressure zone. Far from the front of the working face is the original stress area, while the stress tends to stabilize farther from the rear of the working face. Under these conditions, mining will face the challenges of a complex stress environment and strong dynamic pressure influences, which may lead to tunnel deformation.

Hydraulic fracturing technology This technology is applicable to hard roof strata, breaking the roof through both fracturing and softening methods. The drilling diameter is 56mm, and the inclined depth of the hole is 50m, with fracturing occurring every 3m. Each hole is fractured 14 times, with an injection time of 30 minutes and an injection amount of 80L/min for each time.

Single-row drilling layout technology This technology is applicable for controlling the roof of the tunnel, with drilling arranged 1 meter from the coal pillar side at a 5° angle to the tunnel axis, and a spacing of 10 meters between the drill holes, arranging a single row of holes within a 400-meter area.

The conditions are as follows: the 8th coal seam in the No. 8 mining area of the Dongqu Mine is buried at a depth of approximately 350m, with a total coal seam thickness of 1.52 to 5.04m, a gangue content of 40%, and an annual gangue production of approximately 1.2 million tons. Under these conditions, the large accumulation of gangue on the ground will have a serious impact on the ecosystem surrounding the mining area, and it faces the challenge of restricted surface dumping, which may result in limited production in the mine.

the coal seam in the mining area has 1-2 layers of intercalated gangue, with a directly overlying layer of 3 meters of limestone, a basic overburden of 6 meters of fine-grained sandstone, and a directly underlying layer of 4 meters of sandy mudstone. Under these conditions, the filling of gangue will face technical challenges such as the transportation of filling materials and pushing against the roof, which may affect the filling effect.

Ground Gangue Transportation System This technology uses a tubular belt conveyor (belt width B=1350mm, pipe diameter Φ350mm, capacity Q=800t/h) to deliver the washed ore to the wellhead, equipped with a washing chamber with a capacity of 7500t (Φ15×48m).

Underground gangue transportation system This technology includes a 2029-meter-long gangue discharge channel and a 192-meter-long high-lift transport tunnel, transporting gangue to the filling working face via three belt conveyors.

Goaf filling technology This technology fills the material using a scraper conveyor and a pushing device, progressing by one step distance of the support after every five cuts of coal, sequentially completing the filling operation from the tail to the head of the machine.

The conditions are a burial depth of about 750 m, with a maximum horizontal stress σH = 22.56 MPa, located in a deep high-stress field where horizontal stress exceeds vertical stress, and the angle between the tunnel development and the maximum horizontal principal stress is 42°. Under these conditions, construction will face challenges such as deformation of the surrounding rock in the tunnel, anchor rod disengagement, and tendons pulling out, which may result in poor tunnel formation and the occurrence of smooth and flat intersecting layers in the roof.

the gas content of the No. 3 coal seam is approximately 19.5 m³/t, the coal seam gas pressure is 2.4 MPa, and it is affected by CO2 gas-phase fracturing. Under these conditions, construction will face challenges such as gas outbursts and the destruction of the overall integrity of the surrounding rock, which may lead to roof collapses and significant deformations of the surrounding rock.

Anchor net and cable spraying support technology This technology uses φ22 mm high-strength anchor bolts (steel grade 500), 2400 mm in length, with a spacing of 1000 mm × 950 mm; high-strength low relaxation steel strand anchors φ22 mm, 6300 mm in length, with a spacing of 1000 mm × 1600 mm; and sprayed concrete with a thickness of 150 mm, strength grade C20.

Grouting anchor cable combined support technology This technology uses SKP22-1×19/1860-10300 and grouting anchor cables SKZ29-1/1770-11300 installed in an interleaved manner, with a spacing of 1600 mm×800 mm; the base plate employs grouting anchor cables SKZ29-1/1770-6600, with a spacing of 1600 mm×1600 mm.

the original network uses a backbone layer with a 10 Gigabit ring network and a Gigabit tree network at the access layer, with each backbone ring network switch having one Gigabit port that can connect up to 16 Gigabit integrated sub-stations in a cascaded manner. Under these conditions, network construction will face challenges such as insufficient reliability protection, service congestion, low operational management efficiency, and difficulty in ensuring data transmission quality, which may result in a single device failure affecting the business of an entire area, and consequences such as video services occupying bandwidth.

Conditions are for a high gas mine environment. Under these conditions, the network construction will face the challenge of safety hazards associated with underground fiber splicing operations, which may result in low efficiency during construction and operation.

F5G All-Optical Industrial Network Dual-Ownership Protection Technology This technology achieves a network self-healing time of less than 30ms through Type C dual affiliation protection networking, with zero service interruption during network faults.

10 Gigabit hard pipe technology This technology provides the capability to expand 16 10-giga hard pipelines, with one fiber optic core enabling one 10-giga dedicated video line, and increasing the bandwidth of service access points by ten times.

Smart Network Management System Technology This technology adopts a service-oriented platform architecture design to achieve topological restoration, alarm monitoring, and intelligent data analysis of an all-optical industrial network, providing centralized management, visual monitoring, and intelligent analysis capabilities.

Fiber optic fast connection technology This technology enables instant fiber optic quick connections in seconds without fusion through pre-connected ORP and pre-connected optical cables, reducing the safety risk of electric sparks in underground networks.

The conditions for the B2 coal seam I010203 working face are a hard roof, low coal discharge rate, an inclined length of 192m, an average coal seam thickness of 9.5m, a coal seam dip angle of 14°, and a coal seam apparent density of 1.32t/m3. Under these conditions, mining will face challenges such as the difficulty in breaking the roof and low recovery rates, which may result in reduced efficiency of caving coal.

The conditions are a coal seam burial depth of 450m, with a uniaxial compressive strength of the overburden coal of 23.4MPa, and the immediate roof composed of mudstone. Under these conditions, mining will face the challenge of strong stability of the roof structure. If the flatness and strength of the roof are not weakened, the roof structure can be equivalent to a 'fixed-supported beam', which is not easy to break.

Slot blasting technology for cutting eyes This technology is suitable for conditions with a hard roof, by weakening the treatment at the cutting point, changing the roof structure from a 'fixed beam' to a 'cantilever beam', making the roof more prone to fracture.

Advanced pre-cracking blasting technology This technology is applicable to the area with an initial spacing of 35m, borehole diameter of 94mm, hole spacing of 7000mm, and a loading amount ranging from 80 to 160kg, using the reverse loading method.

the overall groundwater level of the northern slope is high, and the surface soil has experienced long-term weathering, resulting in reduced strength. Under these conditions, the slopes will face the risk of shear failure, which may lead to large-scale landslide disasters.

the slope is mainly composed of mudstone, and the surface mudstone is exposed after mining, subjected to long-term physical and chemical weathering. Under these conditions, the shear strength of the slope is reduced, making it prone to horizontal displacement under horizontal stress, which may trigger a large-scale landslide.
Qingfang load reduction technology This technology can improve the slope stability coefficient from 0.998-1.057 to 1.111-1.267 through the slope reduction and load reduction plan.
Anti-slip pile technology This technology is applicable for fixing upper soft rock to the underlying bedrock, which can enhance the overall stability of the slope.

the coal seam in the coal pressing area of the highway bridge is buried at a depth of 480m, with a seam thickness of 3.86m, the immediate roof consisting of sandy mudstone with a thickness of 9.8m, and the old roof consisting of sandy mudstone with a thickness of 11.5m. Under these conditions, mining will face deformation challenges such as surface cracking, tilting, twisting, and step-like surface irregularities, which may cause bridge damage, lead to traffic interruptions and accidents, and pose a threat to the safety of people's lives and property.

The conditions include the presence of the F2-1 fault (with a drop of 30 to 60 meters and an inclination of 55°) and the F2-2 fault (with a drop of 20 to 80 meters and an inclination of 70°) in the mining area. Under these conditions, mining will face the challenge of relative movement between the upper and lower plates of the fault, resulting in step-like subsidence at the fault outcrop, which may lead to a step difference of more than 1/3 of the surface subsidence value.

Stripping Mining Technology This technology is applicable to coal mining, utilizing a strip arrangement of 50m extraction and 60m retention, which allows the remaining strip coal columns to fully support the load of the overlying rock layer, forming a single uniform subsidence basin with minimal induced deformation.

Probability Integral Method Subsidence Prediction Technology This technology is suitable for predicting surface displacement and deformation. By utilizing parameters such as a subsidence coefficient of 0.2 and an influence angle tangent of 2.4, it predicts deformation data such as a maximum subsidence value of 259mm and a maximum tilt value of 1.58mm/m.

a certain coal mine has remaining reserves of about 5 million tons, and the mine's production capacity has decreased from the original 4.8 million tons per year to 900,000 tons, with significant pressure on the tunnel roof. Under these conditions, mining will face the challenge of low coal resource recovery rates, which may lead to a reduction in the lifespan of the mine.

The conditions are as follows: the working face 81041 is 138m long and 250m wide, with a mining height of 2.8m and an average coal seam dip angle of 6.5°; the working face 81043 is 99m long and 347m wide, with a mining height of 2.2m and a burial depth of 197 to 256m. Under these conditions, mining will face the challenges of poor stability of the surrounding rock and roof collapse, which may result in tunnel deformation and instability of the working face.

Roof pre-cracking cutting seam technology This technology is applicable for pre-cracking the top plate of the cut section using hydraulic fracturing methods, with a drilling depth of 15m, a spacing of 20m, and an inclination angle of 63°29. It can achieve pre-cracking and pressure relief of the top plate.

Temporary support technology for tunnels This technology includes advanced support areas (0~30m), temporary support areas behind the framework (0~200m), and support for the roadway stabilization zone, using a combination of π-shaped steel beams, single hydraulic props, I-beams, etc., which can ensure the stability of the tunnel.

The conditions indicate that the mining area belongs to the typical overturned structure of the locality, having undergone multiple overlapping overturned movements, resulting in an unconsolidated sliding surface. Under these conditions, mining will face the risk of slope landslides, which could result in safety production accidents.

The conditions are poor rock mechanics properties, such as the compressive strength of RAT formation mudstone dolomite being only 9.175-20.728 MPa and the compressive strength of conglomerate being 12.044 MPa. Under these conditions, the rock mass is weak and fractured, posing a risk of slope instability, which may lead to a progressive retrogressive landslide.

The conditions are located in southern-central Africa, where there are long rainy seasons and frequent heavy rainfall events. Under these conditions, monitoring will face challenges such as equipment being affected by weather and unstable monitoring effects, which may lead to the failure of monitoring alerts.

Slope radar monitoring technology This technology has a monitoring accuracy of 0.1mm, a monitoring range of over 5km, can operate normally in adverse weather such as rainfall, and achieves fully automated long-term real-time monitoring.

Implicit modeling technology This technology can construct a three-dimensional detailed geological model that includes eight types of strata: Q, Ki, CMN, SD, RSC, RSF, RAT, and Br, for slope stability analysis.
Numerical simulation technology Using FLAC3D software for slope stability analysis, a safety factor of 1.25 was obtained through a strength reduction coefficient simulation of 1.0 to 1.25.

The conditions involve severe water influx in the eastern wing transport tunnel of the second mining area, with an inflow rate of up to 2332 m³/h, causing the tunnel to be flooded, with the highest flooding point difference reaching over 110 meters. Under these conditions, mining will face challenges such as high pressure in the drainage system and damage to the original tunnels, which may result in the inability to produce normally in the secondary mining area.

The conditions indicate that the expected normal inflow rate after water discharge will increase from 538 m³/h to 3066 m³/h, and the maximum inflow rate will increase from 724 m³/h to 4143 m³/h. Under these conditions, mining will face the challenge of insufficient drainage system capacity, which may result in flooding and production interruptions.

Ground Grouting Technology This technology is applicable to the water outlet area, where grouting is carried out from the surface through construction grouting holes to seal the underground water outlet points and the nearby fractured zones, modifying the aquifer, reinforcing the impermeable layer, and sealing the water outlet fractures.

Direct discharge surface drainage system This technology uses 8 MD450-90×7 type pumps (6 in operation and 2 as backup), and 4 pipelines of φ377×15 (3 in operation and 1 as backup), with a drainage capacity of up to 4400 m³/h.

The condition involves a significant overlay of coal resources along the South-to-North Water Diversion pipeline, exceeding 50 million tons. Under these conditions, mining will face challenges such as a high risk of pipeline damage and unclear mechanisms of extraction damage, which may lead to safety issues with the pipelines.

The conditions are a large pipe diameter for the water supply line (700mm) and a single-layer extraction thickness of 8.5m. Under these conditions, the extraction will face the challenge of severe impacts on the pipelines due to mining activities, which may lead to deformation and damage of the pipelines.

ABAQUS numerical simulation technology This technology is applicable to the analysis of pipeline and soil subsidence deformation. By constructing the constitutive relationship of the pipe-soil system through the Ramberg-Osgood model and the Mohr-Coulomb model, it can simulate the movement and deformation characteristics of pipelines under different working conditions.

STL-24 multi-channel acoustic emission monitoring system This technology is applicable for pipeline damage monitoring, and with 24 sensors deployed in safe and vulnerable areas, it enables full-time damage monitoring of the pipeline.

The conditions are as follows: coal seam thickness is large, with an average thickness of 5.38m, and the cross-sectional area of the tunnel is 20.4m². Under these conditions, the support will face the challenge of high difficulty, which may result in the deformation and instability of the tunnel.

the coal seam uses the top-coal caving method for recovery, and the mine pressure is relatively strong. Under these conditions, supporting will face the challenge of significant deformation of the surrounding rock in the tunnel, which may lead to consequences such as roof separation and instability.
Anchor bolt support technology Use Φ22mm×2500mm left-handed threaded steel anchor rods, with a spacing of 900mm×1000mm between the roof and spacing of 1000mm×1000mm between the sidewalls.
Anchor cable support technology Use Φ22mm×8300mm high-strength low-relaxation steel strands, arranged in a '3-2-3' configuration, with spacing of 1600mm×2000mm and 2000mm×2000mm.

Side excavation and support construction technology Timely support is provided using the method of 'cutting 1 row and supporting 1 row,' which includes procedures such as laying metal mesh and installing construction anchor bolts and cables.

The conditions are a thick layer of hard direct roof, with the direct roof consisting of light gray to dark gray bioclastic limestone, thickness ranging from 7.2 to 10.25 meters, rock uniaxial compressive strength of 40 to 65 MPa, and a P-wave velocity coefficient of 4.0 to 6.5. Under these conditions, the support will face challenges such as low support efficiency, insufficient pre-stress, and low rigidity of the protective material, which may result in consequences such as the netting phenomenon and swelling of the surrounding rock.

The conditions are for a shallowly buried tunnel, with a burial depth of about 100 meters and a ground pressure of approximately 2.5 MPa. Under these conditions, support will face challenges such as significant deformation of the tunnel sidewalls and a relatively soft floor that is prone to heaving, which may result in a reduction in the overall stability of the tunnel.

Large-span anchor net support technology This technology is suitable for shallow-buried thick hard roof roadways, with four Φ18×1800mm anchors installed in the roof, spaced 1200×1000mm apart; each side will have three anchors of the same model, spaced 1100×1000mm apart; for the first 5m before the opening, two Φ17.8×6300mm rock bolts will be reinforced, spaced 2000×2400mm apart.

High pre-stress support technology This technology uses an anchor bolt prestressing force of 40 to 60 kN, an initial tension force of 80 to 120 kN for the anchor cable, combined with H-shaped steel beams and Φ4mm welded mesh to achieve a high-strength and high-rigidity support effect.

the 2-2 coal seam currently being mined in the mine has entered the late recovery stage, and preparations for the lower level development work need to be made in advance. Under these conditions, the horizontal extension will face the challenge of high production continuity pressure, which may result in a decrease in mine capacity.

there are 8 exploitable coal seams in the mining area, with the 3-1 coal seam averaging 2.15 meters in thickness and an average distance of 38.24 meters to the 2-2 coal seam. Below, there are additional coal seams 4-2, 4-3, 4-4, and 5-2. Under these conditions, multi-coal seam mining will face challenges such as complex coal seam occurrences and difficulties in system connectivity, which may result in resource loss and wasted investments.

The conditions involve the existing 7 shafts of the mine and a complete surface facility system. Under these conditions, horizontal extension needs to consider how to make reasonable use of existing facilities to avoid the challenges brought by redundant construction; otherwise, it may lead to excessive investment consequences.

Main inclined shaft direct extension technology This technology is applicable to the existing main inclined shaft extending downwards, making full use of the original equipment and facilities, with simple construction, low investment, uncomplicated system, and fewer transfer links.

Extended technology for dark auxiliary inclined shafts This technology is suitable for the extension of the auxiliary lifting system, allowing for changes in the shaft excavation direction, reducing the protected coal pillar, and not affecting the production at the first level and construction at the second level.

Overlapping gallery layout technology This technology arranges the 3-1 main coal roadway, auxiliary coal roadway, and return air roadway in overlapping positions beneath the 2-2 coal central roadway, which can reduce the amount of tunnel work required.

The conditions are an area of 176.942 km², with complex terrain located in the southeastern part of the Loess Plateau in Longdong, exhibiting typical landform characteristics of the loess plateau. Under these conditions, site selection for industrial areas will face challenges such as terrain openness and earthwork volume, which may lead to increased construction costs and greater difficulty in construction.

The conditions are characterized by a moderately complex coalfield structure, with eight gently dipping back thrusts in the axial NEE-SWW direction, containing three extractable coal seams, of which the 8-2 coal seam accounts for 73.48% of the reserves. Under these conditions, the layout for development will face challenges such as the stability of coal seam occurrence and mining sequence, which may affect the mine's production capacity and mining efficiency.

it is a high-gas mine, with the possibility of coal dust explosion and self-ignition tendency, and the hydrogeological conditions are moderate. Under these conditions, the layout of the production system will face challenges such as safety production and ventilation systems, which may increase operational costs and safety risks.

Vertical Shaft Development Technology This technology is suitable for deep mining, employing a main and auxiliary shaft + return air shaft scheme, with the main shaft at a depth of 835m, the auxiliary shaft at 835m, and the return air shaft at 1115m, capable of meeting the annual production demand of 5.0 Mt/a.

Site Selection Technology This technology proposes three site options (Chenjiawan, Sigou Village, Fengjiashan) by analyzing factors such as terrain conditions, external facilities, and transportation conditions to achieve optimal site selection.

External transportation system This technology includes solutions such as railway transportation and bridge transportation, among which the bridge transportation solution is 2.2 km long with an investment of 62.92 million yuan, enabling efficient connection with the supporting power plant.

the industrial site in the mine has been established, with three shafts (main inclined shaft, auxiliary inclined shaft, and return air inclined shaft) completed. Below ground, in addition to the main inclined shaft, auxiliary inclined shaft, and return air inclined shaft, which have been constructed to level 4-2 coal, no other tunnel projects have been constructed. Under these conditions, the exploration design will face challenges such as tightening environmental policies and changes in related industry policies and regulations regarding intelligent construction, which may result in the original design being unable to meet the needs of guiding the construction of underground sections.

the mining area is approximately 6.5113 km², with five exploitable coal seams: 3-1, 4-2, 4-3, 4-4, and 5-2, with interlayer distances ranging from 10.17m to 47.28m. Under these conditions, the exploratory design will face the challenges of multi-seam mining and significant variations in seam spacing, which may result in a complex and inefficient exploratory system.

Coal gate contact technology This technology is used for the connection of various horizontal tunnels with main, auxiliary, and return air inclined shafts, which can simplify the process and improve efficiency.
Coal bunker contact technology This technology is used for the connection between the 3-1 coal main transportation system and a horizontal connection, enabling efficient transportation.

Strip mining technology This technology is suitable for coal seams with small spacing (such as 4-2, 4-3 coal seams with a distance of 13.45m), utilizing a horizontal large roadway strip mining method, which can reduce the engineering workload of the tunnels.

the W3305 auxiliary transport roadway is connected to the northern wing belt roadway and is at the same elevation as the W3303 belt transport roadway, with the W3303 belt transport roadway connected to the W3305 belt transport roadway via the #1 connecting passage. Under these conditions, the layout of the tunnels will face the challenge of cross-arrangement of main and auxiliary transportation tunnels on the same level and the inability to meet the direct installation of belt conveyors, which may result in low transportation efficiency and difficult maintenance.

Partial cantilever interchange technology This technology is suitable for the cross arrangement of tunnels, with local roof raising carried out in the W3303 belt conveyor opening section. The dimensions of the roof raising are 4.2m wide, 3.3m high, and a maximum raising thickness of 3.1m, using anchor mesh cable support, with an anchor bolt spacing of 800×800mm.

Semi-interchange wind bridge structural technology Use 11# I-beams (6.6m long) as the bridge frame, with 70mm thick large plates for the bridge deck, and pour 500mm thick reinforced concrete walls on both sides; the space below should not be less than 3600mm, with C20 concrete sprayed.

Tape basic construction technology Build a belt foundation with a width of 4.1m at a slope of 4°47′, with a 200mm pull-down in the foundation area, using 300mm square stone combined with concrete to construct the surrounding wall.

The conditions are a high geostress environment, with vertical stress ranging from 11.5 to 18.2 MPa, maximum horizontal stress from 10.3 to 15.8 MPa, and an average burial depth of 453 m. Under these conditions, the support will face the challenge of rapid accumulation of initial deformation of the surrounding rock, which may result in consequences such as roof leakage or the need for repeated support.

The condition involves the combined effect of advanced support stress at the working face and lateral support stress in the mined-out area, with the influence increasing as the distance to the coal wall decreases. Under these conditions, the support will face challenges such as the exacerbation of plastic failure of the surrounding rock in the tunnel and severe section shrinkage, which may result in consequences such as roof subsidence, floor heave, bulging of the two sides, and even roof collapse accidents.

Prestressed high-strength anchorage reinforcement technology This technology uses Ф21.6mm×7200mm pre-stressed high-strength anchors, with a pre-tensioning force of no less than 220kN. The spacing between anchors is 1400mm in double rows, with a spacing of 3600mm, arranged at an angle of 20° to the normal direction of the ceiling.

Original anchor network cable combined support technology This technology uses Ф22mm×2200mm top anchor bolts with a spacing of 830mm×900mm; Ф18.9mm×7200mm top anchor cables with a pre-tension of 150kN; and Ф22mm×2200mm side anchor bolts with a spacing of 900mm×900mm.

The conditions are a coal seam thickness of 6.8 to 10.8 meters (average 8.8 meters), an inclination angle of 3° to 5° (average 4°), medium development of coal seam layering and joints, with the roof being sandy mudstone or mudstone, and locally coarse-grained sandstone, while the floor mainly consists of mudstone. Under these conditions, tunneling will face challenges such as significant dust pollution and the risk of gas exceeding limits, which may lead to health hazards and safety risks for the workers.

The conditions are influenced by the erosion of ancient river flows, resulting in a thinning of the coal seam within the excavation range, a change in the cap rock lithology from mudstone to sandstone, and the presence of fractured structures. Under these conditions, excavation will face challenges such as roof rock fragmentation and increased water inflow, which may lead to difficulties in roof management and drainage issues.

Directional drilling technology This technology involves constructing large-diameter advanced drilling (210mm) within the space of the advance excavation tunnel, ensuring that the drilling is accurately directed to be located in the upper part of the excavation section, with a horizontal spacing of about 1.5m.

Negative pressure extraction system This technology achieves the extraction and discharge of dust and gas by connecting the gas water separator and negative pressure pipeline, with a cumulative gas extraction volume of 221,000 m³ at Luling Mine.

The JM mine is a typical large porphyry copper deposit, with low ore grade (average copper grade of 0.53%). The deposit strikes NW-SE, dips SW at an angle of 45° to 55°, with a length of approximately 1450m, a width of about 360m, and a vertical extension of about 1400m. Under these conditions, carrying out the lowering operation will face challenges in the formation of the lowering space and control of rock collapse, which may result in insufficient fracturing or excessive crushing of the ore.

The direction of the maximum principal stress within the rock mass is approximately vertical to the strike of the mineral body, making an angle of about 49° with true north. Under these conditions, performing bottom pulling operations will face the challenge of uneven stress distribution, which could lead to stress concentration in the bottom pulling area or severe damage to the bottom structure due to disturbances caused by rock collapse.
Optimization technology for lauding height This technology evaluates the impact of different pulling bottom heights of 6m, 8m, and 10m on mineral rock collapse through comparison.

Optimized technology for the direction of pulling the bottom forward. This technology analyzes the rock collapse laws under different pushing directions by setting two pull-bottom advancing directions, which are perpendicular to and parallel to the maximum principal stress direction.

Incremental control technology for bottom area. This technology employs a rectangular pull-bottom shape, with the long axis and short axis increasing in length by increments of 7.5m and 5m, respectively, maintaining a length-to-width ratio of 1.5 to control the growth rate of the pull-bottom area.

the average coal thickness of the 3-5 coal seams in the Tashan coal mine is 17.93m, containing more than 5 to 10 layers of interburden, with a complex structure and a mining-to-production ratio of 1:2.99. Under these conditions, mining will face the issue of ineffective waste rock handling, which may result in increased transportation costs, decreased quality of raw coal, and increased pressure on surface washing, among other consequences.

the mine produces approximately 850,000 tons of gangue annually, with surface gangue discharge or landfill in the surrounding ravines of the mining area. Under these conditions, the treatment of gangue will face environmental pollution issues, which may conflict with the '3060' carbon neutrality goals and the trend of increasing social awareness of environmental protection.

Intelligent dry selection technology This technology is suitable for coal gangue separation ranging from 25 to 300 mm, with a gangue-to-coal ratio of 1% to 3% after separation, and a coal-to-gangue ratio of 3% to 5%. The maximum processing capacity of a single unit is 280 t/h, and it requires no water or medium, allowing for remote centralized control.

Roller screen separation technology This technology is suitable for the preliminary classification of raw coal, with a processing capacity of 4000 t/h and a screening efficiency of ≥95%, making it suitable for underground operating environments.

there is localized water influx in the lateral drift at a depth of 1400 to 1900 meters, mainly concentrated in the section from 1600 to 1800 meters, with a maximum water influx of 46.2 m³/h. Under these conditions, construction will face the challenges of large water inflow and limited drainage capacity, which may result in flooding accidents.

The conditions include the presence of stratigraphic overturn outcrops in the eastern mining area, with developed fracture layers in the lithological variations of surface mudstone, granite, and limestone. Under these conditions, construction will face the challenges of gradually widening fracture channels and increased water conductivity, which may result in water and sand breakdown and damage to the horizontal tunnel.

Shallow and deep hole combination curtain grouting technology This technology uses an alternating arrangement of deep holes (6m) and shallow holes (3m), with a diameter of 42mm, a spacing of 2.0m for shallow holes, a spacing of 2.0m for deep holes, and a discharge spacing of 3.0m, with a total of 1536 grouting holes arranged.

Double-liquid-single-liquid composite grouting technology Shallow holes and slurry running areas use a dual liquid slurry of cement and water glass (volume ratio 1:1), while deep holes use a single liquid cement slurry (water-to-cement ratio 0.75:1 to 1:1). The grouting pressure for shallow holes is 1.0 to 1.5 MPa and for deep holes is 2.0 to 4.0 MPa.

Drainage diversion technology On both sides of the wellbore bottom plate, drainage ditches are to be constructed, with a diversion hole placed every 20 to 50 meters, totaling 13 diversion holes. The holes will have a depth of 2 to 5 meters and a diameter of 42 mm.

The conditions require the working face to rotate approximately 37°, passing through multiple old tunnels and several intersection points (including six-way junctions, two four-way junctions, and a three-way junction). Under these conditions, rotary mining will face challenges such as the mode of entry for the coal cutter, control of hydraulic supports and conveyor status, and roof management, which may lead to large-scale frame deformation or roof collapses and other production accidents.

The conditions are a track elevation difference of 21m, and the working face will expose the 14318 track in the later stage of rotation. Under these conditions, rotary mining will face challenges such as the up-and-down movement of the transport equipment and difficulties in managing the roof, which may lead to abnormal equipment operation and roof accidents.

Fixed-point rotation mining technology This technology employs a method where the front of the machine only cuts without advancing, and the rear of the machine advances 3.75 meters each time, completing a 37° rotation through 52 cycles, with 33 brackets at the front side being straight and the brackets at the rear side being fully tensioned in the chamber.

Control technology for brackets and conveyor systems This technology uses two side guard plates in conjunction with a single bottom support box to achieve vertical adjustment of the support against the coal wall, and controls the direction of the conveyor by adjusting the support angle (from 75° at Support No. 1 to gradually vertical at Support No. 50).

Complex roof management technology This technology includes measures such as reinforcing the head with 20-50 sets of double mesh and I-beams, adjusting the flexible connections of head frames 1-5, and supporting the tail with 15 sets of double-layer metal mesh I-beams.

the coal seam inclination angle is between 25° and 45°, which belongs to the steeply inclined coal seam. Under these conditions, the support will face challenges such as easy cracking at the junction of the sidewalls and the roof, uneven stress on the sidewalls, and significant deformation differences between the roof and the top plate, which may result in poor tunnel stability.

the roof of the working face is composed of a gray-black sandy shale layer (thickness 2.50m), and the upper roof is made of medium-grained quartz sandstone (thickness 40m). Under these conditions, support will face the significant challenge of the high risk of coal seam bottom bulging and seismic pressure disasters, which may result in tunnel destruction.

Anchor bolt support technology This technology is applicable to tunnel support, with the roof using bolts of 22mm diameter and 2000mm length, spaced 700mm apart, with 5 per row; the two sides using bolts of 22mm diameter and 2000mm length, spaced 500mm apart, with 3 per row.

Anchoring cable reinforcement technology This technology is suitable for supporting reinforcement of the top and bottom plates, using anchor cables with a diameter of 17.8mm and a length of 4500mm. The spacing between the top plate anchor cables is 200mm, and the spacing between rows is 1400mm; both the spacing and row distance of the bottom plate anchor cables are 1400mm, with 2 cables per row.

The conditions are characterized by large cross-sectional mining of coal and deep mining, with complex geological conditions, especially the presence of weaker surrounding rock and high surrounding rock stress. Under these conditions, supporting the tunnel will face challenges such as poor stability of the surrounding rock and limited excavation progress, which may lead to deformation and damage of the surrounding rock and suboptimal support effectiveness.

The conditions include the working face cut eye guiding tunnel roof containing 2-3 layers of stable intercalated gangue, primarily composed of carbonaceous mudstone and sandy mudstone, with localized development of fractures. Under these conditions, the support will face challenges such as weak roof and poor self-stability of the surrounding rock, which may result in roof collapse and roof deformation.

Anchor rod support technology This technology utilizes φ22mm high-strength left-handed threaded steel and φ20mm high-strength left-handed threaded steel anchor rods, with a length of 2.4m and a spacing of 800mm × 800mm. The pre-tensioning torque for the top anchor rods and side anchor rods is 152N·m and 125N·m, respectively.

Anchor cable reinforcement technology This technology uses 19 strands of φ21.8mm steel strand anchor cables, with a length of 8.3m, arranged in a 3-4-3 step layout, positioned in the middle of the anchor rod row.
Mesh support technology This technology uses a steel mesh with a mesh size of 100mm×100mm, welded from φ6mm round steel rods, with a 100mm overlap.

The conditions are a working face advance length of 4412m, a strike length of 277m, and a coal seam height of 8.6m with a large mining height. Under these conditions, support work will face challenges such as large tunnel spans and high support difficulty, which may lead to safety accidents such as roof falls and side collapses.

the direct top is fine-grained sandstone (13.5~16.5 MPa) and the basic top is mudstone (11.3~13.3 MPa). Under these conditions, support will face challenges such as relatively low surrounding rock strength and poor stability, which may result in roof deformation and delamination.

the cross-section of the auxiliary transport belt is rectangular, with a width of 5.4m, a height of 4.7m, and a cross-sectional area of 25.38m². Under these conditions, support will face challenges such as large cross-sectional dimensions and ample support space, which may result in suboptimal support effectiveness.

Roof support technology This technology uses left-handed helical rebar anchors with a diameter of 20mm and a length of 2.1m, with both spacing and row spacing set at 1m, paired with anchors of 17.8mm in diameter and 6.5m in length, with spacing of 2.5m and row spacing of 3m, using MSZ2360 resin anchoring agent and metal mesh for support.

Two-support support technology This technology uses fiberglass anchor rods with a diameter of 20mm and a length of 1.5m, installed with a spacing and row spacing of 1m, perpendicular to both side walls, in conjunction with 8# steel wire welded metal mesh for support.

the original main shaft was constructed in the 1970s and 1980s, with rough workmanship, a topsoil layer of 240mm thick red brick masonry, and a bedrock section that is unlined and unsupported, with the support system being old and showing signs of aging. Under these conditions, extending the well will face challenges such as significant safety hazards in the shaft and poor stability of the surrounding rock, which may lead to shaft collapse and casualties.

The conditions require the wellbore to be expanded from a net diameter of 3.0m (net cross-sectional area of 7.07m²) to a net diameter of 5.0m (net cross-sectional area of 19.63m), with a wellbore depth of 187.783m. Under these conditions, the well expansion will face challenges such as enlarged cross-sections and increased construction difficulty, which may affect construction efficiency and quality.

Shaft boring machine drilling method This technology uses the MSJ5.8/1000/1000 type vertical shaft boring machine, capable of excavation to a depth of 800m and a diameter of 5.8m, with a drilling speed of 0.5 to 0.7m/h, a maximum torque of 1000kN·m, and a total power of 4×110kW.

Integrated parallel operation process This technology achieves integrated parallel operations for drilling, rock breaking, mucking, temporary support, and permanent support. The surface layer is supported by 400mm thick reinforced concrete (C30), while the bedrock section uses 400mm thick plain concrete (C30) for support.

there are over 30 existing slurry pumps in the key area of the Taiyuan coal preparation plant, adopting a maintenance model primarily based on point inspection and regular repair. Under these conditions, equipment management will face challenges such as unknown equipment health status and reliance on human experience, which may lead to frequent production stoppages and result in safety hazards.

Wireless sensor monitoring technology This technology constructs a wireless mesh network through MESH self-organizing network technology, using Zigbee modules and 4G/5G networks to transmit data such as temperature, vibration, current, voltage, flow, and pressure.

Equipment early warning system technology This technology includes threshold warnings, trend amplification warnings, and trend acceleration warnings, enabling early detection and effective tracking of equipment anomalies.
Intelligent diagnostic technology This technology performs fault localization through equipment models and inference engines, achieving automatic diagnosis of conventional faults.

there are numerous buildings distributed in the Taibai Lake area, including the Taibai Lake North and West Dikes, the North Lake Pavilion, the Shuanglong Bridge, the Four Faces Buddha statue, and the Jining Cultural Center, among other important structures. Under these conditions, mining will face challenges such as protection of surface buildings and control of mining impacts, which may lead to consequences such as building damage and surface subsidence.

The conditions involve the presence of a very thick magmatic rock layer in the overburden, with an average thickness of 134 meters and an average distance of 375 meters to the top boundary of the third coal seam. Under these conditions, mining will face challenges such as shock ground pressure and sudden fractures, which may lead to instability of the tunnels, subsidence, and sudden surface sinking.

The conditions for the working face layout need to consider the direction of the fault, as the faults in the area are relatively developed. Under these conditions, mining will face challenges such as fault water conduction and complex layout of the working face, which may lead to consequences like flooding in the mining area and low production efficiency.

Technical Measures for Preserving Coal Pillars in Building Protection This technology is suitable for the protection of important buildings. According to regulations, protective coal pillars are reserved for buildings such as Beihu Pavilion, Shuanglong Bridge, and the Four-Faced Buddha statue to ensure the safety protection of these structures.

Probability Integral Method for Settlement Prediction Technology This technology is applicable for predicting surface subsidence, using parameters such as subsidence coefficient q=0.65 and horizontal movement coefficient b=0.45 to predict and control the impact of mining on the surface.

Joint layout technology for work surfaces This technology is suitable for mining under complex geological conditions, reducing the construction workload of the tunnel by overlapping the upper and lower working faces of the coal seams in a 3-above, 3-below arrangement.

The 36408 comprehensive mining working face has a length of 321 meters, coal seam thickness ranging from 2.8 to 6.0 meters, with an average thickness of 4.7 meters, and an inclination angle of 0 to 19°. The absolute gas outflow is 8.12 m³/min. Under these conditions, the mining operation will face the challenge of gas easily accumulating at the upper corner, which may exceed limits, with gas concentrations reaching 0.3% to 0.8%, surpassing the safety threshold, potentially leading to gas accidents.

Suspended drag pipe extraction technology In the return air roadway, arrange the Φ325mm steel pipe to extend 5 to 20 meters towards the working face along the coal wall's tangent direction, and replace the Φ200mm corrugated hose to extend to the back of the 1# support column.

Buried pipeline extraction technology Arrange the extraction pipeline in the negative pressure area, with the pipeline end located 5 to 30 meters behind the goaf, and a spacing of 20 meters between the pipelines.

High-position drilling fracture extraction technology Arrange 4 boreholes at a distance of 30m outside the inclined cutting eye of the return air lane, with a diameter of 113mm, an inclination of 22.1° to 25.8°, and a depth of 66.6 to 81.5m.

PLC frequency conversion control technology Using the CPU315-2DP controller and the CM3000-CT710G frequency converter to control the operation of the 2BEC-72/2BEC-100 water ring vacuum pump in real-time.

The conditions are a flotation concentrate production of 1.02t/h, a concentration of 29%, a dry specific gravity of the concentrate of 3.21t/m³, a pH value of the concentrate slurry of 8.12, and a -200 mesh proportion of 60% to 85%. Under these conditions, the transportation will face challenges such as unreasonable pump pool design, high foam content, and oversized pump selection, which may result in consequences like pipeline blockage, high energy consumption, and rapid equipment wear.

the existing conveying system uses DN110mm×10mm PE pipes, with a total length of 96m, and has 4 90° right-angle elbows. Under these conditions, the transportation will face challenges such as large pipe diameter and high local resistance, which may result in low slurry flow rate, pipes being "not fully flowing," and increased risk of blockage.

Pipeline optimization design technology This technology is based on a critical flow speed of 1.45 m/s, using a DN63×5.8 mm PE pipe, molded in one piece throughout, with a bend radius of R=150 mm (R/d=3), which can reduce the resistance coefficient to 0.135.

Pump pit improvement design technology This technology adopts a one-use-one-backup form, with an inclined pool wall angle of 55°, an effective volume of 0.4m³, and a spacing of more than 1.2m between the two pumps, equipped with a 25PNJ pump (flow rate of 12m³/h, lift of 14m).

Defoaming Optimization Technology This technology effectively achieves defoaming by increasing the feed water pressure, setting multiple circular nozzles to increase the spray area, and adjusting the pulp concentration to 11%.

The conditions are characterized by complex geological features at the working face, with an average coal seam thickness of 8.5m, containing three layers of interburden with a thickness of 0.2 to 0.3m each. The roof consists of coarse-grained sandstone (15m), fine-grained sandstone (12m), and mudstone (1.32m). Under these conditions, the mining operation will face challenges such as difficulty in roof collapse and high support pressure, which may result in caving accidents or impact the efficiency of the mining operation.

there is an inflow problem at the working face, with severe seepage at the local recovery working face, and the inflow amount ranges from 6 to 18 m³/h. Under these conditions, the mining recovery will face challenges such as the threat of water hazards and high drainage pressure, which may result in water accumulation in the working area and interruptions in production.

Deep hole loosening blasting technology This technology utilizes the strong shock waves and high-temperature, high-pressure gases generated by the explosion of explosives in a semi-infinite medium to form a compressed crushing zone, and achieves overall damage to the rock mass through the expansion of fractures.

Advanced deep hole blasting pre-loosening roof technology This technology uses a parallel arrangement of blast holes along the working face of the slot, with hole lengths ranging from 65 to 130 meters, a diameter of 75 mm, and a single hole charge weight of 100 to 270 kg, executed through a series detonation method for blasting.

New segmented blasting technology for loading explosives This technology uses air bags for segmented loading, and by adding a modified reinforcing cap to the detonator area, it can reduce costs by nearly 20% and optimize the fragmentation of the blast.

the tunnel cross-section is restricted, with a height varying between 3.2 to 3.7 meters and a minimum cross-section width of 3.8 meters. Under these conditions, transportation will face the challenge of limited space, which may result in large equipment being difficult to pass through or low transportation efficiency.

The conditions include a steep transportation route, with a maximum slope of 16° for the auxiliary incline and a slope length of 1083m. Under these conditions, transportation will face the challenge of high climbing ability requirements, which may result in transportation accidents and safety hazards.

The conditions require the transportation of large equipment, with the maximum single item being a hydraulic support, weighing 30 tons and measuring 7850×1650×2000mm. Under these conditions, transportation will face the challenge of difficulties in transporting heavy loads and large-sized equipment, which may result in difficulties in transloading and low efficiency.

Explosion-proof diesel engine monorail crane technology This technology is suitable for underground transportation in coal mines, capable of carrying a load of 48 tons, with a climbing ability of 25°, and an operating speed of 2.5 m/s, adapting to a minimum tunnel height of 3.4 m.

Heavy railway suspension technology This technology uses 1140V heavy rails, 2.4m long straight rails, double anchor chains with four anchor cables suspended, and a single point anchor load of no less than 100kN, capable of meeting transport requirements for loads over 30t.

Ultra-low clearance hydraulic lifting beam technology This technology is suitable for low clearance environments, with a clearance height of only 400mm, and can transport a 2m high integrated hydraulic support within a 3.4m high aisle.

The conditions are a shaft净 diameter of 8.2m, a vertical depth of 466m, a shaft wall made of a single layer of reinforced concrete with a support thickness of 600mm, and the need to equip two sets of lifting systems. Under these conditions, the equipment design will face challenges such as ensuring the safe and high-speed operation of containers and transporting large equipment, which may lead to safety hazards such as shaft deformation and equipment damage.

the maximum terminal load of the wire rope is large: wide cage 575 kN, wide balance weight 475 kN, narrow cage 425 kN, narrow balance weight 345 kN. Under these conditions, the equipment design will face challenges such as high stress on the tank track and a high risk of deformation, which may result in unstable operation of the lifting system.

Optimizing Tank Rail Design Technology This technology uses Q345 steel, with a wide tank cage beam model of 220mm×220mm×12mm, a balance hammer beam model of 200mm×200mm×10mm, and an interlayer spacing of 5.0m, which can meet the requirements for heavy load lifting.

Differential coupling device technology This technology sets up a mine shaft differential coupling device at elevation levels such as -193.000m and -423.000m, with a telescoping range of 150mm for each horizontal layer, which can prevent safety hazards caused by deformation of the shaft.

High-Strength Composite Material Technology The ladder room uses pull-pull type fiberglass materials, with a tensile strength of ≥500 MPa, compressive strength of ≥400 MPa, and flexural strength of ≥500 MPa, which are stronger than conventional materials.

The conditions are an increase in mining depth and a rise in the surrounding rock stress in the tunnels. Under these conditions, tunnel support will face the problem of surrounding rock instability, which may lead to safety incidents such as local roof falls and collapses.

The conditions are characterized by the development of joint fractures in the surrounding rock of the tunnel, with structural filling materials swelling and becoming slippery upon contact with water, resulting in serious water seepage. Under these conditions, the support will face challenges such as layering spalling of the roof and wedge failure, leading to the failure of the original seam-type anchor support.

Barton rock mass quality (Q) classification method This technology comprehensively evaluates rock mass quality through six parameters: RQD, Jn, Jr, Ja, Jw, and SRF. It is applicable to both soft and hard rocks and can account well for the effects of high ground stress conditions.

Combined support technology The combined support method using resin anchor bolts (φ20×2000mm, spacing 0.8×0.8m) + steel strips + metal mesh + 50mm thick sprayed concrete is suitable for Class III surrounding rock.

the basic roof of the working face is limestone, with a thickness of approximately 8.0m, well cemented, a mudification coefficient of only 0.39, no obvious layering, good integrity, and a burial depth of 389 to 218m. Under these conditions, mining will face challenges such as strong pressure from the roof and large-scale overall collapse of the goaf, which may threaten the safety of the personnel and equipment.

The conditions are a working face height of 3.2m, a width of 120m, and two chutes with lengths of 1230m and 1205m respectively. Under these conditions, mining will face challenges such as high support load and high stress intensity in the working face, which may affect the safe and efficient production of the working face.

Deep hole blasting pre-cracking technology This technology is suitable for weakening hard roof strata by arranging pre-splitting drill holes in the cut and panel, with 8 pre-splitting drill holes arranged in each chamber and a drilling spacing of 30 meters, effectively reducing the pressure strength of the roof.

Roof support technology This technology uses the ZY5200/11/24 type self-moving hydraulic support, with a support strength of 0.79 MPa, to achieve roof control through the 'thick layer roof broken block - coal body - support' support system.

the 22nd coal seam of the Taiyuan group in the Donggucheng Coal Mine of Luyun has a tendency for spontaneous combustion, with a coal seam coefficient of 22.05%. Under these conditions, mining will face the risk of spontaneous combustion of coal seams, which may result in significant economic losses and, in severe cases, could cause casualties.

Grouting fire prevention system This technology uses loess as the grouting material, with a particle size of less than 2mm and a sand content of 25% to 30%. XFJ-1 type suspending agent is added, with a daily grouting amount of 306.75m³ and a daily working time of 15 hours.

Nitrogen Fire Prevention Technology This technology injects N2 with a volume fraction greater than 97%, ensuring that the O2 volume fraction in the goaf is below 7%, with a nitrogen injection flow rate of 10 m³/min.

Fire-retardant technology for flame inhibition This technology uses industrial calcium chloride (CaCl2·5H2O) as an inhibitor, with a mass fraction of 20%, a density of 1.11t/m³, and an initial spray amount of 3.55t on the working face, with daily spraying once during normal extraction.

Bundled tube monitoring system This technology conducts monitoring in the intake airway and return airway, setting up one monitoring point every 50 meters, with two probes each on the intake and return sides inside the goaf, and one probe in the corner of the return airflow.

The conditions include malfunction states such as deviation, tearing, smoke, and slipping of the belt conveyor. Under these conditions, controlling will face challenges such as equipment downtime and emergency shutdowns, which may result in reduced transportation efficiency and equipment damage.

The condition is to achieve safe, stable, and efficient operation of the equipment. Under these conditions, the control will face the challenge of insufficient effectiveness of the control system, as the original system's effectiveness is only 89%, which may affect the continuous operation of the equipment.

Fault detection and classification technology This technology includes the FDD (Fault Detection and Diagnosis) and FCD (Fault Classifier) modules, which achieve the extraction and classification of fault mode feature vectors through the RBFN network.

Control reference reset technology This technology is implemented through the CRRP (Control Reference Reset) module, which can adjust control parameters based on the type of fault, achieving error correction control and reduction of performance indicators.

Network communication technology Using communication modes such as TCP/IP and Modbus TCP, achieve data transmission between the PLC control system and the fault-tolerant control computer, supporting millisecond-level data refresh.

Under the condition of retreating the 2305 working face, filling soft mold concrete walls beside the roadway exerts dynamic pressure effects on the adjacent working face and its bottom plate. Under these conditions, challenges such as significant deformation of the surrounding rock in the tunnel and obvious stress on the support structure will be faced, which may lead to the formation of stress concentration areas on the coal body side of the 2306 working face.

the vertical stress in the bottom extraction tunnel is 18 MPa, slightly higher than the original rock stress. Under these conditions, there will be challenges with significant stress on the two groups of anchor rods, with some anchor rods reaching their ultimate load, which may lead to the failure of the support structure.

Roof support technology Using No. 22 left-handed threaded rebar anchors (2.4m long), MSCK2350 resin capsules for anchoring, and metal mesh for overhead protection (30mm x 30mm mesh), with a spacing of 950mm between anchors, a spacing of 1000mm from rows, and a pre-tensioning torque of 300-390 N·m.

Heading support technology Use No. 22 left-handed rebar anchor rods (2.4m long), MSZ2350 resin capsules for anchoring, and W steel protective plates (5mm × 280mm × 450mm), with an anchor rod spacing of 950mm, a row spacing of 1000mm, and a pre-tension torque of 300-390 N·m.

FLAC3D numerical simulation technology Establish a 120m × 60m × 80m three-dimensional model, using 28,900 simulated elements, to conduct stability analysis of the surrounding rock based on the Mohr-Coulomb constitutive relationship.

The conditions indicate that there is water accumulation in the goaf area approximately 10 meters above the tunnel roof, which is composed of sandy mudstone. The average thickness of the surrounding rock is 2.63 meters, and the basic roof also consists of sandy mudstone with an average thickness of 4.98 meters. Under these conditions, tunneling will face the problem of roof leakage, which may lead to production safety accidents and hinder construction progress.

Technology for the Arrangement of Water Exploration Drill Holes This technology uses the CMSI-8000/90 model mining deep-hole drilling rig, employing a φ42mm drill bit and φ65mm drill rods, with 7 water exploration and discharge boreholes arranged in a fan shape, drilled to a depth of 70m. Among them, K1-K4 control the leakage from the roof, while K5-K7 control the leakage at the working face.

Series Fan Technology This technology is suitable for overcoming high-resistance ventilation lines, with one FBD No. 6.0 fan (power 2×15 kW) set at -230 m level, and FBD No. 5.6 or No. 6.0 fans configured in series for mid-segment ventilation.

The condition requires accurate measurement of the spatial position and operating trajectory of the cantilevered tunneling machine in a completely enclosed underground space. Strapdown inertial navigation technology This technology uses a FOG type fiber optic gyroscope (zero bias stability ≤ 0.02°/h) and a quartz flexible pendulum accelerometer (range ±30g), capable of independently measuring data such as heading angle, position, speed, and attitude.

Odometer-assisted positioning technology This technology uses an 1100-line electromagnetic odometer, with a drive wheel radius of 75mm and a motor acceleration ratio of 100:1, capable of measuring incremental mileage in both longitudinal and lateral directions.

Dual DSP controller data processing technology Using a dual DSP architecture with TMS320F28335 (150MHz) and TMS320C6784 (300MHz), the functions of data acquisition processing and computation fusion are completed separately.

the particle size composition of the crushed product is relatively coarse, with the -6mm content accounting for only 34.75%. 2YKR2460(H) Circular Vibrating Screen Technology This technology is suitable for heavy load screening operations, reducing the screening load to a reasonable range (70%~80%) by replacing the original 2YAH2160 vibrating screen.

Shaft well technology This technology includes an air intake shaft (diameter 8.0m, net cross-sectional area 38.6m2) and an air return shaft (diameter 8.2m, net cross-sectional area 50.4m2), equipped with facilities such as communication lines and monitoring lines.

Transportation system technology This technology uses belt conveyors for the main transportation system and trackless rubber-wheeled vehicles for the auxiliary transportation system, achieving efficient coal transportation.

The conditions are primarily with mudstone as the surrounding rock, the lithology is light gray coarse-grained sandstone containing quartz and feldspar, with calcareous cementation, characterized by low hardness and swelling when wet. Bolt support technology This technology is applicable to arch and side wall support, using 22# left-handed threaded rebar without longitudinal ribs, with a length of 2.4m and anchoring force of 200kN, in conjunction with W steel protective plates and high-strength fittings, to achieve stability of the surrounding rock.

Anchor cable support technology This technology is applicable for arch support, using Φ18.9mm high-strength low-relaxation prestressed steel strands, with a length of 6.3m and a prestress of 250kN, combined with high-strength bearing plates to enhance the support effect.
Shotcrete technology Using C20 strength concrete with a mix ratio of cement:sand:gravel = 1:2:2, with a spraying thickness of 150mm, to reinforce the surrounding rock through layered spraying.

The conditions are a coal seam buried depth of 168.8 to 200.8 meters (average 185 meters), an average coal seam thickness of 9.5 meters, and a coal seam dip angle of 0 to 5 degrees (average 0.6 degrees). The conditions require the recovery of covered coal resources and marginal coal under buildings, railways, and water bodies.
